Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award Grant: A Monte Carlo and SQUID Magnetometer Study of Molecular Spintronics Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Molecular spin devices (MSDs) are promising candidates for revolutionizing computer logic and memory. MSDs aim to harness the controllable transport and magnetic properties of molecular device elements which can be synthetically mass produced. However, there have been insignificant efforts to predict or measure the effect of molecular coupling on the performance of a MSD.

In order to produce insights about the role of molecular device elements on the magnetic properties of the MSDs, the Research Initiation Award project entitled - A Monte Carlo and SQUID Magnetometer Study of Molecular Spintronics Devices - has two goals: a) To perform Monte Carlo Simulations (MCS) to theoretically investigate the interplay between the magnetic molecules and ferromagnetic electrodes responsible for bringing about the desired characteristics within MSDs. The project will study the effects of Heisenberg exchange coupling between magnetic molecules and ferromagnetic electrodes of a MSD; study the effect of dimensionality, geometry on the molecule induced magnetic coupling, and improvise algorithms for Monte Carlo Simulations near phase change points in a MSD. b) To experimentally study the effect of molecular device elements on the magnetic properties of the MSDs. The research will focus on magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ) based MSDs, by conducting a SQUID magnetometer based magnetization study before and after transforming a variety of MTJ test beds into MSDs by utilizing molecular device elements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcome report for NSF-Research Initiation Award (NSF-RIA) (Grant #HRD-1238802): A Monte Carlo and SQUID Magnetometer Study of Molecular Spintronics Devices (MSDs) from 9/1/2012 to 8/31/2016.

 

PI: Dr. Pawan Tyagi, Mechanical Engineering, University of the District of Columbia, Washington DC, USA-20008

 

This grant has been a true game changer for the PI and University of the District of Columbia (UDC). This grant helped the PI to initiate research in the molecular spintronics area and make a justification to seeking support for the development of UDC’s first Nanotechnology Application Laboratory. Without this grant, the PI could not get the sufficient support in the critical time of his career as an assistant professor at UDC. This NSF grant has enabled the PI to achieve the following three landmarks. (1) Initiate high impact research in understanding the molecular spintronics devices and advance this challenging field. (2) Provide experiential learning for nearly ten undergraduate students in the nanotechnology area and help these students for graduate schools and technologically advanced careers. (3) Initiate nanotechnology laboratory with a class 1000 clean room and a wide range of microfabrication and device characterization resources to promote cutting edge materials and device research at UDC.

This grant has enabled the PI to contribute in the following areas:

 

(1)     Theoretically understanding the impact of molecular coupling on MSDs by conducting Monte Carlo simulations:

The PI proposed to utilize Monte Carlo formalism to reveal the insights related to MSD properties. The PI envisioned that Monte Carlo approach bypasses the limitations of other theoretical approaches. Until 2012 there was no Monte Carlo Simulation program available to predict the properties of MSDs. With NSF-RIA grant we embarked on the task of making simulation code to fill this knowledge gap. We wrote code for the discreet spin model and included all the features promised in the grant. However, this code had several limitations. To resolve this issue, we developed new simulation program by using a continuous spin model to allow a spin vector to assume any state in the spherical coordinates. The continuous model based simulation can efficiently study 1-3D MSDs with as high as 100,000 atoms in few hours. The ability of our code to work with a large number of ferromagnetic atoms and parametric representation of magnetic properties allowed us to approach the actual sub-microscopic scale at which real devices are developed experimentally. For the first time, we provided theoretical insights about the mechanism behind the experimental observations of paramagnetic molecule induced antiferromagnetic coupling between microscopic ferromagnetic electrodes

(http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0957-4484/26/30/305602/pdf ). Our theoretical estimation of molecular coupling strength required for producing unprecedented coupling between two ferromagnetic electrodes matches with the experimental results. Our research has a much border impact as it encompasses a wide range of nanoscale elements utilized as a device element between the two ferromagnetic electrodes.

 

(2)     Conducting experimental study on MSDs:

This NSF-RIA grant has enabled the synthesis of proposed novel molecular nanostructures for the MSDs. A UDC’ chemistry department faculty was supported by this NSF-RIA grant to produce molecules for the experimental MSD research. This grant has enabled the research on the core issue related to the stability of ferromagnetic electrodes for the MSDs. Our recent research revealed that most of the key ferromagnetic electrodes like Cobalt, nickel, and permalloy are fairly stable up to 90 ?C, and aggressively oxidize beyond this temperature under the ambient conditions. We produced the following publications:

 

  1. Tyagi, P., Friebe, E., Baker, C., 2015. Addressing the challenges of using ferromagnetic electrodes in the magnetic tunnel junction-based molecular spintronics devices. J.Nanoparticle Res. 17, 452.
  2. Tyagi, P., Friebe, E., Baker, C., 2015. Advantages of Prefabricated Tunnel Junction Based Molecular Spintronics Devices. NANO 10, 1530002.

 

(3)     Experiential learning for UDC students:

To date, this grant has supported ten undergraduate students. These students were trained in simulation and modeling, microfabrication technology, nanostructure fabrications. This NSF-RIA funding has already impacted the lives of many students. A recent article about the UDC student views and activities has appeared in the following news coverage:

 http://www.foresthillsconnection.com/news/udcs-nanotechnology-program-is-no-small-achievement/

 

The student graduating with the nanotechnology application laboratory and were supported by the NSF grant has been accepted for the Ph.D. program at reputed institutions and also were employed by the advanced research laboratories and government organizations. The PI is also supporting other NSF grants related to nanotechnology education for the UDC community college students. In summary, the NSF-RIA grant has been a revolutionizing catalyst to initiate nanotechnology research and education at UDC. The PI thankfully acknowledge NSF support for supporting UDC to becoming capable of doing cutting edge research in the challenging areas and provide advanced training to students to prepare the 21st-century workforce.
